channel.title: IP Ranges
channel.description:
Basically I am making a SOCKS server in Java to learn more about networking in Java. Any who, I want to implement an unchanging blacklist of peers I do not wish to serve to - this will be read from a file in the format of:
[code] 10.10.1.1/16 [/code] etc
The above means that all address from 10.10.1.1 -> 10.10.255.255 are in that range.
My question is: should I have a large HashMap of the all address in each provides range that is parsed so I could blacklist.contains(addr) or should I have a set/array list of all ranges and iterate through all rangea to find if the provides address is in that range? All in all I suppose this comes down to a CPU vs memory debate.

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

I misunderstood the question; I thought you were proposing using a trie to check if an address is in a range (i.e., populate it with the addresses of that range…), I was a bit worried for a second.

Read full topic

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

c|p:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_Inter-Domain_Routing#CIDR_blocks

see: http://www.icir.org/robin/pysubnettree/
a PATRICIA tree (radix trie) that uses CIDR format 2 make it easier for u

Read full topic

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Classless Inter-Domain Routing

Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR, /ˈsaɪdər/ or /ˈsɪdər/) is a method for allocating IP addresses and IP routing. The Internet Engineering Task Force introduced CIDR in 1993 to replace the previous addressing architecture of classful network design in the Internet. Its goal was to slow the growth of routing tables on routers across the Internet, and to help slow the rapid exhaustion of IPv4 addresses. IP addresses are described as consisting of two groups of bits in the address: the most signi...

Read full topic

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

super_:

hmph… it’s like a heap in the sense it is ordered, but that’s it. nobody said a chained hash table, that sounds retarded considering it is not apt for the job. you should provide a map-like interface over a trie.

Yeah, I’ve started reading examples in Java regarding tries and it look like the exact solution I need.

Read full topic

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

hmph… it’s like a heap in the sense it is ordered, but that’s it. nobody said a chained hash table, that sounds retarded considering it is not apt for the job. you should provide a map-like interface over a trie.

item.title: IP Ranges
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

super_:

you can provide the facade of a map if you’d like, however using a hash table is not the best solution. it is best if it is backed by some sort of ordered prefix tree, like frank_ said.

So somewhat of a chained hashtable? Or am I interpreting this wrong.

Edit:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trie looks somewhat like a heap?

Read full topic

Basically I am making a SOCKS server in Java to learn more about networking in Java. Any who, I want to implement an unchanging blacklist of peers I do not wish to serve to - this will be read from a file in the format of:

10.10.1.1/16

The above means that all address from 10.10.1.1 -> 10.10.255.255 are in that range.

My question is: should I have a large HashMap of the all address in each provides range that is parsed so I could blacklist.contains(addr) or should I have a set/array list of all ranges and iterate through all rangea to find if the provides address is in that range?
